summary_points: 1. PulteGroup, Inc. reported first-quarter 2025 net income of $523 million ($2.57 per share), a decrease of 21% year-over-year.
2.  Home sale revenues decreased by 2% year-over-year to $3.7 billion in Q1 2025, reflecting a 6% increase in average sales price offset by a 7% decrease in closing volume.
3.  The company repurchased $300 million of its common shares in Q1 2025 and had $1.9 billion remaining under its share repurchase authorization as of March 31, 2025.

1. Genuine Parts Company reported first-quarter 2025 sales of $5.9 billion, a 1.4% increase year-over-year, driven by acquisitions, partially offset by a decrease in comparable sales and negative currency impacts.
2.  First-quarter 2025 diluted EPS was $1.40, down from $1.78 in the same period of 2024, while adjusted diluted EPS was $1.75 compared to $2.22 in the prior year.

3. The company reaffirmed its full-year 2025 outlook, predicting revenue growth of 2% to 4% and adjusted diluted EPS of $7.75 to $8.25, but this excludes the potential impact of new U.S. tariffs and a one-time, non-cash pension plan termination charge expected in late 2025 or early 2026.
1. Lockheed Martin Corp reported first-quarter 2025 sales of $18.0 billion, a 4% increase year-over-year.
2.  First-quarter 2025 free cash flow was $955 million, a decrease of $202 million compared to the same period in 2024.

3. Lockheed Martin reaffirmed its 2025 financial outlook (as of April 22, 2025), but this outlook excludes the impacts of certain  uncertainties, including the Next Generation Air Dominance announcement.
1. Kimberly-Clark's Q1 2025 net sales of $4.8 billion were down 6.0 percent year-over-year, primarily due to currency impacts, divestitures, and business exits; organic sales declined by 1.6 percent.

2.  Kimberly-Clark's 2025 adjusted operating profit is now expected to be flat to positive on a constant-currency basis, a significant downward revision from the previous expectation of high single-digit growth due to reassessed costs, including geopolitical uncertainties.
3.  Adjusted free cash flow for 2025 is now projected to be approximately $2 billion, a decrease from the previous expectation of more than $2 billion, reflecting incremental profit pressures.
1. RTX Corp (formerly Raytheon Technologies Corp) reported strong Q1 2025 results on April 22, 2025, with sales up 5% year-over-year ($20.3 billion) and adjusted EPS up 10% year-over-year ($1.47).

2. Collins Aerospace saw an 8% increase in Q1 2025 sales year-over-year, driven by a 13% increase in commercial aftermarket sales, while Raytheon's sales were down 5% year-over-year, but up 2% excluding divestitures.
3.  RTX forecasts adjusted sales of $83.0 - $84.0 billion for the full year 2025, with 4 to 6 percent organic growth, but this outlook excludes the potential impact of recently enacted tariffs.
1. Moody's Q1 2025 revenue reached a record $1.9 billion, an 8% year-over-year increase.
2.  Moody's lowered its full-year 2025 adjusted diluted EPS projection range to $13.25 to $14.00 from $14.00 to $14.50, reflecting revised macroeconomic assumptions.
3.  Revised macroeconomic assumptions for 2025 include significantly lower projected GDP growth in the U.S. and Euro area (0.0%–1.0% each) and higher U.S. inflation (3.5%–4.5%).

1. Verizon's Q1 2025 financial performance showed improved EPS, revenue, and net income compared to Q1 2024, with EPS reaching $1.15 (up from $1.09) and total operating revenue reaching $33.5 billion (a 1.5% year-over-year increase).

2.  Verizon's total unsecured debt decreased to $117.3 billion by the end of Q1 2025, down from $128.4 billion at the end of Q1 2024, and its net unsecured debt to consolidated adjusted EBITDA ratio was 2.3 times.

3.  Verizon forecasts total wireless service revenue growth of 2.0% to 2.8% and adjusted EBITDA growth of 2.0% to 3.5% for the full year 2025, with a free cash flow projection between $17.5 and $18.5 billion.
1. Halliburton's Q1 2025 net income was $204 million ($0.24 per diluted share), a significant decrease from Q1 2024's $606 million ($0.68 per diluted share).
2.  Total revenue for Q1 2025 was $5.4 billion, an 8% decrease compared to Q1 2024's $5.8 billion.
3. Halliburton repurchased approximately $250 million of its common stock and paid dividends of $0.17 per share in Q1 2025.
1. Pentair plc reported first-quarter 2025 sales of $1.0 billion, a 1% decrease year-over-year, while adjusted EPS rose 18% to $1.11.
2.  As of March 31, 2025, Pentair plc had $400 million available for share repurchases.
3. Pentair plc updated its full-year 2025 GAAP EPS guidance to approximately $4.27 to $4.42 and maintained its adjusted EPS guidance of approximately $4.65 to $4.80 (as of April 22, 2025).

1. On April 21, 2025, Invesco Ltd. agreed to repurchase $1 billion of its preferred stock from MassMutual at a 15% premium, funding the purchase through debt financing and expecting the transaction to close in May 2025.

2.  This $1 billion repurchase represents 25% of Invesco's outstanding preferred stock, leaving MassMutual with $3 billion of preferred stock and approximately 18.2% ownership of Invesco's common shares.

3. Invesco anticipates the repurchase will be earnings accretive starting in the second half of 2025, improving its balance sheet flexibility while allowing for continued growth investments and share repurchases.
1. MSCI Inc. reported strong first-quarter 2025 financial results (ended March 31, 2025), with operating revenues up 9.7% year-over-year to $745.8 million and diluted EPS up 15.2% to $3.71.
2.  Year-over-year, asset-based fees increased by 18.1%, significantly outpacing the 7.7% increase in recurring subscription revenues.
3. MSCI provided full-year 2025 guidance, projecting operating expenses between $1.405 and $1.445 billion, and adjusted EBITDA expenses between $1.22 and $1.25 billion.

1. Northrop Grumman's first-quarter 2025 sales decreased by 7% year-over-year to $9.5 billion, primarily due to lower sales at Space Systems and Aeronautics Systems, partially offset by higher sales at Mission Systems and Defense Systems.

2.  The company incurred a $477 million pre-tax loss ($397 million after-tax) on the B-21 program's five low-rate initial production options in Q1 2025, primarily due to increased manufacturing costs from accelerating production.

3.  As of April 22, 2025, Northrop Grumman reaffirmed its 2025 guidance for sales ($42,000-$42,500 million) and free cash flow ($2,850-$3,250 million), despite the B-21 loss and acknowledging potential impacts from macroeconomic factors, but not accounting for potential government shutdowns or spending cuts.

1. Quest Diagnostics reported first-quarter 2025 net revenues of $2.65 billion, a 12.1% increase year-over-year (YoY), driven by acquisitions, enterprise accounts, advanced diagnostics, and expanded health plan access; however, organic requisition volume decreased by 0.9% YoY.
2.  As of April 22, 2025, Quest Diagnostics reaffirmed its full-year 2025 guidance, projecting reported diluted EPS between $8.62 and $8.87, and adjusted diluted EPS between $9.55 and $9.80.

3. The company anticipates further impacts to earnings related to special items throughout 2025, including restructuring and integration charges, and the amount of excess tax benefits is dependent on unpredictable factors like employee stock option exercises and stock price.

1. Invesco Ltd. reported $17.6 billion in net long-term inflows for the fiscal quarter ending March 31, 2025, primarily driven by ETFs and Index, Fundamental Fixed Income, and China JV & India, but partially offset by outflows from other areas.
2.  Compared to Q1 2024, Invesco's Q1 2025 U.S. GAAP diluted EPS increased by 22.6% to $0.38, while its adjusted diluted EPS rose by 33.3% to $0.44.

3.  Invesco announced a $1 billion repurchase of its Series A Preferred Stock (expected in May 2025) and a new strategic partnership with Barings, supported by a $650 million initial investment from MassMutual, to scale private wealth offerings.
1. 3M's GAAP sales for the first quarter of 2025 were $6.0 billion, a 1.0% decrease year-over-year, while adjusted EPS increased by 10% year-over-year to $1.88.
2.  Adjusted operating income margin increased by 2.2 percentage points year-over-year to 23.5% in Q1 2025.
3. 3M updated its 2025 guidance to an adjusted EPS range of $7.60 to $7.90,  with an additional tariff sensitivity of $(0.20) to $(0.40) per share.
1. Equifax's Q1 2025 revenue was $1.442 billion, exceeding February guidance by $37 million and showing 5% local currency growth despite headwinds in U.S. hiring and mortgage markets.
2.  Despite a 9% decline in U.S. mortgage hard pull credit inquiry volume in Q1 2025, Equifax anticipates further declines of approximately 11% in Q2 2025 and 12% for the full year.
3.  The company's board authorized a $3 billion share repurchase program (to be completed over four years) and a 28% dividend increase, reflecting strong free cash flow and a positive balance sheet.
1. GE Aerospace's Commercial Engines & Services segment saw a significant 35% year-over-year profit increase to $1.92 billion in the quarter ending March 31, 2025.
2.  GE Aerospace's liabilities increased by $350 million in the quarter ending March 31, 2025, primarily due to increased long-term service agreement liabilities.
3. GE Aerospace anticipates a $0.1 billion income tax expense from the global minimum tax in the future.

1. As of April 22, 2025, GE Aerospace (formerly General Electric Company) reported Q1 2025 results showing an 11% increase in GAAP revenue to $9.9 billion and a 38% increase in non-GAAP operating profit to $2.1 billion.
2.  Year-over-year (YoY), GE Aerospace's adjusted EPS increased by 60% to $1.49, while free cash flow decreased by 14% to $1.4 billion.

3.  Despite maintaining its full-year 2025 guidance, GE Aerospace's guidance now incorporates the net impact of announced tariffs, low-single-digit departures growth (previously mid-single-digit), and delayed spare engine deliveries.
1. Danaher Corporation's Q1 2025 revenue decreased by 1.0% year-over-year to $5.7 billion, while non-GAAP core revenue remained flat.

2.  For Q2 2025, Danaher forecasts low-single-digit year-over-year growth in non-GAAP core revenue, and for the full year 2025, they maintain their expectation of approximately 3% year-over-year growth in non-GAAP core revenue, with adjusted diluted net earnings per common share guided to be in the range of $7.60 to $7.75.

3. Danaher's outlook acknowledges a more dynamic macroeconomic environment since the start of 2025, but expresses confidence in their ability to maintain differentiation due to their strong balance sheet and resilient portfolio.
1. Elevance Health's Q1 2025 operating revenue increased 15.4% year-over-year to $48.8 billion.
2.  Despite a $1 billion year-over-year decrease, Q1 2025 operating cash flow remained at $1 billion due to temporary working capital issues.
3. As of April 22, 2025, Elevance Health's FY 2025 adjusted diluted EPS guidance remains at $34.15 to $34.85.
1. Danaher Corp's Q1 2025 revenue decreased by 1% year-over-year, primarily due to negative currency exchange impacts.
2.  The company anticipates several hundred million dollars in additional tariff costs in 2025, aiming to offset this through cost-saving measures.
3. Danaher divested a product line in Q1 2025, generating a pretax gain of $9 million.

1. As of April 22, 2025, News Corp's stock repurchase program has already spent approximately US$662,676,239.16 on Class A and Class B shares, leaving US$337,323,760.84 remaining under the US$1 billion authorization.
2. On April 21, 2025, News Corp repurchased 32,228,746 shares; 21,592,897 Class A shares for US$439,715,724.10, and 10,657,149 Class B shares for US$222,960,515.06.
3.  News Corp's buyback program anticipates purchases through September 22, 2021,  although the SEC filing notes this is subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. On April 17, 2025, PPG Industries Inc. elected Leon J. Topalian, CEO of Nucor Corporation, to its board of directors, effective July 16, 2025.

2. In 2024, PPG sold approximately $3,167,000 of products and services to Nucor and purchased approximately $1,288,000; these figures decreased to $917,000 and $246,000, respectively, in the first quarter of 2025.
3. Mr. Topalian's appointment to PPG's board may create potential conflicts of interest given the existing business relationship between PPG and Nucor.
1. Sherwin-Williams shareholders approved a new equity and incentive compensation plan on April 16, 2025, authorizing the issuance of up to 21,969,555 shares.
2. At the 2025 Annual Meeting, shareholder votes eliminated supermajority voting requirements in the company's charter, reducing the required vote for certain matters from two-thirds to a majority.

3.  Shareholder approval of the 2025 Equity and Incentive Compensation Plan (Proposal 3) resulted in 192,866,409 votes for and 8,816,376 votes against, with 920,464 abstentions and 19,185,575 broker non-votes.

1. On April 21, 2025, Zimmer Biomet Holdings, Inc. completed its acquisition of Paragon 28, Inc. for $13.00 per share in cash plus a contingent value right (CVR) potentially worth an additional $1.00 per share.
2.  Paragon 28's shares ceased trading on the New York Stock Exchange on April 21, 2025, and will be delisted.

3. Zimmer Biomet anticipates that this acquisition will strengthen its position in the high-growth foot and ankle segment of the medical device market, which is estimated to be worth ~$5 billion and growing at a high-single digit rate.
